Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Intelligent Restoration System for a Self-healing Smart Grid

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall goal of this project is to achieve a self-healing smart grid by creating an intelligent power restoration system. As such, the power system restoration remains a great concern in the evolving smart grid. The lack of online adaptive restoration tools leads to an incredibly long time for system recovery after a major blackout, due to the stochastic nature and uncertainties associated renewables such as wind and solar power resources. The proposed intelligent power restoration system is to create a self-healing power grid by overcoming the challenges that prevent electric power grid from system recovery. The advances are in the development of an intelligent power restoration system that will provide system operators with real-time adaptive restoration actions by including the use of renewable energy in the restoration process and assisting system planners to make long-term investment decisions on blackstart resources including renewable resources. This project will have a significant impact on national grid, sustainable energy and energy security. The potential economic impact is expected to save the loss of several millions of dollars that result from blackouts. The short and long term societal impact addresses national needs, especially for highly interconnected power system, in terms of sustainability, security, and reliability. Situational intelligence in power system restoration minimizes impacts of blackouts and leads to rapid recovery from natural disasters such as earthquakes, hurricanes and malicious attacks. The proposed research will promote teaching, training and learning about smart grid to graduate and undergraduate students; provide hands-on experiences to power engineers in automated power system restoration; and offer learning platform to K-12 students to cultivate the interest in power and energy systems with overarching goal of recruiting underrepresented minority, women and Native Americans students.

This collaborative project proposes to apply emerging computational intelligence techniques including scalable adaptive dynamic programming based on cellular computational networks to design the power restoration system. The goals are; (1) to develop an online adaptive restoration tool using advanced scalable computational intelligence techniques; (2) investigate a novel scheme to use renewable resources in system restoration; (3) explore a blackstart unit investment strategy to improve the self-healing capability; and (4) implement and demonstrate the feasibility of new system on real-time utility power systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to create a self-healing electric power grid. We have accomplished the following achievements from this award:

1. An online adaptive restoration tool to assist the self-healing process

1) A two-stage adaptive decision support system has been developed for bulk power system restoration, including the comprehensive models of generation system start-up, transmission system energization, and load restoration. It determines restoration actions in planning and real-time phases, and adapts to constantly changing system conditions. 2) The distributed load restoration in unbalanced active distribution networks has been developed, providing step-by-step restoration actions to schedule the output of distributed energy resources (DERs) and distribution system control devices. 3) A distributed strategy for integrated transmission and distribution systems restoration has been developed to provide the coordinated restoration for transmission and distribution system operators by sharing limited information of boundary buses in an iterative procedure. 4) A cellular computational network approach for frequency situational intelligence (FSI) in a power system was developed to provide faster than real-time information for grid operators to make appropriate just-in-time control decisions.

2. A new scheme to harness renewable and distributed energy resources in system restoration

1) A novel restoration planning tool for harnessing wind energy has been developed to provide the scheduled wind power, based on stochastic optimization models and two-stage decomposition techniques. 2) Based on the two-stage adaptive robust optimization models and decomposition algorithms, a novel coordination strategy of wind and pumped-storage hydro units has been developed to accommodate wind power uncertainty and variability, increase the total energy served, and reduce wind power curtailment. 3) The optimal strategy to harness battery storage system, electric vehicles, and microgrids has been developed for distribution system restoration, including a distributed cooperative method to control the high penetration of solar PV for resilient distribution systems.

3. An optimal strategy to enhance the resilience of cyber-physical systems

The resilience of cyber-physical system, including power grid, communication system, and transportation system has been investigated. 1) The recent development on the impact of extreme events on power system resilience has been reviewed, including the application of smart grid technologies to provide faster restoration and enhance cyber-physical system resilience. 2) A survey has been delivered on utilizing social media as a platform to extract and analyze abstract data to produce intelligent information, which can be utilized to plan and implement resources towards power grid resiliency from micro level (consumers) to macro level (cities/states). 3) Adaptive and resilient restoration strategies have been developed to recover cyber-physical systems from cyber attacks. It will advance the knowledge of interdependent critical infrastructure recovery after cyber attacks, and provide recommendations to improve system security and resiliency. 4) A controller self-tuning methodology has been developed for power electronic interfaces (PEIs) with particle swarm optimization capability. The optimal parameters for both kW-scale and multi-megawatt PV systems? inverters are determined via a time domain performance objective function.

4. A testbed for real-time implementation of intelligent restoration system

The cyber-physical test beds have been developed in Siemens Digital Grid Lab at UCF and in Real-Time Power and Intelligent Systems (RTPIS) Laboratory at Clemson University. The UCF campus grid model is built in Siemens Microgrid Management System software and real-time simulation platform, OPAL-RT. The FSI systems are then implemented on two different scales of power systems at the RTPIS Lab, one of which installed a large photovoltaic plant. A real-time power system simulator with a weather station is then used to derive typical FSI for demonstration in a control center-like facility at RTPIS Lab.

Moreover, two new graduate courses, Power System Resilience and Advanced Microgrid Design and Operation, have been developed at UCF. Additional modules are added to existing graduate courses at Clemson. The developed testbeds with real system model and data provide a platform for implementation and demonstration. It not only provides students hands-on experience, but also help train power professionals and engineers in recovering power grid from outages and blackouts.

The developed adaptive restoration tool is able to recover power grid following an outage caused by extreme events of natural disasters or cyber intrusions/attacks. It utilizes various DERs, including PV, storage, electric vehicles, and microgrids, to coordinate the recovery process from different networks. This tool together with developed models and algorithms greatly enhance the resilience of power grid and other critical infrastructure.

This research has advanced the knowledge of operating power systems in emergency mode(s), opened the door to using renewable generators to assist and expedite the restoration process, and helped system planner make the long-run decisions of blackstart unit investment. The developed intelligent restoration system has made a great step towards building a self-healing smart grid.

The project outcomes include 1 book and 2 book chapters, 15 journal and 14 conference papers, 1 provisional patent, 30 invited talks and 10 organized panels at international conferences.
